But not everybody knows that the ‘first impression’ is actually only a seven-second window upon first meeting someone. This means that in an interview situation, you need to act quickly in order to make a brilliant first impression on your interviewers.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}},{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-span-mark\",\"data\":{\"style\":{\"color\":\"#669900\"}}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"smile! \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"– Your facial expression is very important when it comes to making a good impression. You need to make sure your expression is saying more about you than words could in a split second. You need to come across as warm and outgoing. They need to spend all seven seconds thinking you are confident and professional.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DON’T \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}},{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-span-mark\",\"data\":{\"style\":{\"color\":\"#A72014\"}}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"forget to introduce yourself!\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" – Chances are, the interviewers know who you are. But even so, just introduce yourself. It breaks the ice and gives you a conversation topic for the first few seconds. Every one of the seven seconds needs to be productive, so don't waste any on random topics - you are there to talk about you, so do so right from the beginning.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"separatorBLock\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Lifehacks from English language instructor \",\"marks\":[]},{\"object\":\"inline\",\"type\":\"link\",\"data\":{\"url\":\"https://telescope.epam.com/who/Yelena_Makarkina\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Yelena Makarkina\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\":\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Kill your excessive filler words \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"– Eliminate words such as ‘so,’ ‘you know,’ ‘like’ and ‘well’ from your vocabulary so that your listener can focus solely on your message.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"In general, we use filler words because we are thinking. Maybe we are searching for the right word or need to stop and formulate our next sentence. It's okay to let a few filler words slip out. After all, it's a natural part of speaking. No one is going to think less of you if you say ‘so’ once in a while. The goal is to avoid saying it every three words. Filler words aren't the enemy — excessive filler words are.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Don’t be afraid to slow down a bit. If your mouth moves faster than your brain, you're going to use a lot more filler words. If you slow down, you'll not only cut out the filler, but you'll be much more understandable.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Back up your statements \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"– People often make sweeping general statements, not expecting to be challenged to support them. Each claim you make must be based on facts that you can quickly recall and articulate. There should be at least one example that illustrates your general statement.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Grammatical Errors\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" – Avoid using incorrect grammar or slang. Expressions such as ’ain't,’ ‘she don't,’ ‘me and my colleague’ and ‘so I goes to him’ aren't appropriate. Be sure to speak in complete sentences and use the right tenses.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Sloppy Speech \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"– Slurring words together or dropping their endings impairs the clarity of your message.
